title: Land Rig Logistics & Contingency Planning
description: Operational decision-making around land rig specific logistics challenges including remote locations, weather, and supply chain

scenario.context: You're drilling on land rig CC-LAND-150 in a remote desert location. Nearest supply base is {{distanceToBase}} km. Current section is {{holeSize}}" at {{currentDepth}} m. Weather forecast shows {{weatherCondition}} for the next 48 hours.

questions.question: You have {{bariteTonnes}} tonnes of barite on location. Based on your current MW of {{mudWeight}} sg and potential need to weight up to {{targetMW}} sg, do you have enough? When should you order resupply?
questions.correctResponse: Calculate: Volume to weight up = Active system + hole volume. Barite required = (Target MW - Current MW) × Volume × specific calculation. For remote locations, maintain minimum 3-day buffer stock plus emergency reserve. Order point should be when stock reaches 5-day consumption + transport time. In this case: if road transport takes {{transportDays}} days, order when you reach {{orderPoint}} tonnes remaining.

questions.question: A sandstorm is forecast to hit the location in 6 hours and last 24-48 hours. What preparations should you make and at what point do you consider suspending operations?
questions.correctResponse: Immediate preparations: 1) Secure all loose equipment, 2) Close air intakes on engines/compressors, 3) Cover sensitive equipment (MWD, electronics), 4) Position pipe safely (either at shoe or with contingency casing depth planned), 5) Full fuel and water tanks, 6) Verify communications backup. Suspension criteria: visibility <50m, wind >60 km/hr, or sand ingestion risk to engines. Decision point: 2 hours before forecast arrival - make go/no-go call.

questions.question: You've experienced a major equipment failure (top drive/mud pump) and the replacement part is {{partLeadTime}} days away. What are your options to minimize NPT while waiting?
questions.correctResponse: Options to minimize NPT: 1) If safe to leave pipe in hole - use time for maintenance, BOP testing, training, 2) If rotary table available (top drive failure) - evaluate if can continue limited operations, 3) If must suspend - position well safely, document hole condition, prepare for restart. Productive activities: Full rig maintenance, crew training/drills, review procedures, pre-stage materials for next section. Always: detailed handover notes for repair crew, lessons learned documentation.

discussionPoints: How does supply chain planning differ between land and offshore operations?
What minimum stock levels should be maintained for critical materials?
How do you balance cost of inventory vs risk of stockout?
What communication systems are essential for remote land operations?
